bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Bertha L. Lyons, May 15, 1948

div1.p: Hench discusses Cuban attitudes toward the “Reed versus Finlay” debate, and describes his reaction to a threatened protest by the Cuban delegation. Hench was careful to include Finlay items in his exhibit and slide show, and to praise Finlay in his lecture.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Bertha L. Lyons, May 15, 1948
div1.opener:
May 15, 1948
Miss Bertha L. Lyons
Assistant to the Director
Hall of Fame
1 Madison Avenue
New York, New York
My dear Miss Lyons:
div1.p:
I have just returned from an eastern trip which included the exercises
to commemorate the demonstration ofby Walter Reed of the mosquito transmission of
yellow fever, before the Fourth International Congress on Tropical Medicine.
In connection with this, may I discuss two points.

1. The attitude of the Cubans towards “Reed versus Finlay”. You are
probably familiar with some of this. Most Cubans believe that Americans neg-
lect Finlay and give all the credit to Reed, and certainly the Cubans give
practically all the credit to Finlay and none to Reed. The argument is an
unfortunate one and there is much to be said for the Cuban viewpoint because
there are many American textbooks that don't even mention Finlay in the dis-
cussion of yellow fever. In Cuba there are dozens of memorials to Finlay,
many in Havana alone and although there is a bust of Lazear, there is no bust
of Reed and indeed his name is not even mentioned on the pediments of any of
the various memorials. However, so far as I know, there is not a single statue
or memorial to Finlay in the United States. Indeed there aren't many to Reed
except of course the Walter Reed Hospital and the Schuler busts. In any event,
we were disturbed in Washington by the attitude of certain Cuban delegates.

Under the auspices of the Surgeon General's Office, there was at the
Congress an exhibit on Walter Reed. I was asked to bring certain material and
I purposely included three items on Finlay. Two days before the memorial cere-
mony, a Havana newspaper published a statement something to the effect that “As
usual the Americans are completely ignoring Finlay, etc., etc.” The word was
passed to the Cubans in Washington (or vice versa). Anyhow, I was informed that
a group of angry Cubans were seen examining the Walter Reed exhibit and talking
in very excited tones on Tuesday morning. Later that morning a delegation visited
Doctor Soper much disturbed at the “neglect of Finlay”. They stated they were
in the mood to present a formal protest to the State Department. Doctor Soper
and I had long been aware of this controversy and I had taken great pains to in-
clude in my illustrated lecture a photograph of Finlay, one of his paper and
another slide quoting him. Furthermore, I side-stepped the basic controversy
and without disetracting from Reed, praised Finlay highly. Doctor Soper revamped
his remarks considerably and at the ceremony Wednesday evening apparently we
satisfied the Cubans because afterwards several came up to me and expressed
their “deep appreciation”, etc. One of the prominent young Cuban physicians
is Dr. Pedro Nogueira who in the last administration had a fairly high govern-
mental position in the Health Department. He is now out politically and is now
only health officer for Marianao but is nevertheless a dominant figure among
younger Cubans. He is a very dynamic young man and is writing a book on the

May 15, 1948
conquest of yellow fever. He is much more fair than most Cubans and recognizes
the relative importance of the work of Finlay and Reed. After my talk and after
he expressed his appreciation of it, he admitted to me that the University of
Havana had that day wired him asking him to confirm or deny the Havana newspaper
reports of the day before. He told me that he was entirely satisfied with
what Doctor Soper and I had said, that it was “entirely perfect” and that he
was cabling Havana to that effect.

Now, I have told you all this so that you can avoid this trouble which
the Congress ran into. Of course there will be few Cubans at your ceremony
but rest assured that there will be those in the audience who will be deliberately
looking for slights to Finlay and who will report the same to Havana. I am sure
that your speakers all know of this controversy, certainly General Bliss and
Doctor Sawyer do. But if possible, the newspaper reporters should get matters
straight. Our Washington ceremony was reported in two or three papers and
one paper reported my talk in some detail. Again, nobody mentioned Finlay.
If therefore, you have any way of asking the New York reporters to give Finlay
due credit, I think you could help along the cause of Cuban-American amity.

2. Doctor Nogueira is now in New York. He heard of your ceremony
and is very anxious to come. He will be at the Governor Clinton Hotel, New
York City, May 17 to 31. His wife and five-year old son are with him. May
I earnestly suggest and request that you telephone him and invite him personally
to the affair. I don't think his wife or son would attend it (perhaps they would)
but I know he wants to and in all fairness to him he is trying hard to show Reed's
part in his book.

I had a grand time with the Reed's in Washington, a delightful dinner
the evening of the 12th, etc. General Reed told me that as he understands it,
the or that is to meet him at the Pennsylvania Hotel will pick me up at the
Waldorf the morningafternoon of the 20th. The Reeds are coming in the morning by train
and leaving late that afternoon by train. If it would be more convenient for
all concerned, why don't I meet them at the Hotel Pennsylvania; on the other
hand, if they are coming up town anyhow, I suppose they could call for me at
the Waldorf. I will do whatever you wish. I will arrive at the Waldorf about
10 the morning of the 20th. Could you leave some sort of a message instructing
me what to do?

I note on the invitation that “academic robes may be worn but are not
obligatory”. I shall therefore bring my gown.
div1.closer:
Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. PSH:alc
